{{college color boxes|Michigan Wolverines}} |nickname = [[Michigan Wolverines|Wolverines]] |sporting_affiliations = [[NCAA Division I]] – [[Big Ten Conference|Big Ten]] |website = {{url|www.umich.edu}} |logo = University of Michigan logo.svg |logo_upright = 1.0 }} The '''University of Michigan''' ('''UM''', '''U-M''', '''U of M''', '''UMich''', or '''Michigan''') is a [[public university|public]] [[research university]] in [[Ann Arbor, Michigan]]. Founded in 1817 in [[Detroit]], as the [[History of the University of Michigan#The Catholepistemiad (1817–1821)|''Catholepistemiad'']], or the ''University of Michigania'', 20 years before the [[Michigan Territory|territory]] became a state, the university is [[Michigan]]'s oldest. The school was moved to Ann Arbor in 1837 onto {{convert|40|acre|ha}} of what is now known as Central Campus. Since its establishment in Ann Arbor, the flagship university campus has expanded to include more than 584 major buildings with a combined area of more than {{convert|780|acre|km2}} spread out over Central Campus and North Campus, two [[satellite campuses]] in [[University of Michigan–Flint|Flint]] and [[University of Michigan–Dearborn|Dearborn]], and a [[University of Michigan Detroit Center|Center]] in Detroit. The university is a founding member of the [[Association of American Universities]]. Michigan has ranked among the best public universities in the United States by major college and university rankings.{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=September 9, 2020|title=Top Public Colleges & Universities|url=https://www.usnews.com/best-colleges/rankings/national-universities/top-public|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=18 January 2021|website=U.S. News & World Report}}{{Cite web|date=2020-10-07|title=Best public universities in the United States 2021|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/student/best-universities/best-public-universities-united-states|access-date=2021-01-18|website=Times Higher Education (THE)|language=zh-hans}}{{Cite web|title=2021 Top Public Universities in America|url=https://www.niche.com/colleges/search/top-public-universities/|access-date=2021-01-18|website=Niche|language=en}} The university is [[Carnegie Classification of Institutions of Higher Education|classified]] among "R1: Doctoral Universities – Very high research activity".{{Cite web |url=https://carnegieclassifications.iu.edu/lookup/view_institution.php?unit_id=170976 |title=University of Michigan Carnegie Classification |date=2020 |publisher=[[Indiana University]] |access-date=January 3, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200103002116/https://carnegieclassifications.iu.edu/lookup/view_institution.php?unit_id=170976 |archive-date=January 3, 2020 |url-status=live }} Michigan offers doctoral degrees in the humanities, social sciences, and [[STEM fields]] (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) as well as professional degrees in architecture, business, medicine, law, public policy, pharmacy, nursing, social work, public health, and dentistry. At $12.48 billion in 2020, Michigan's [[Financial endowment|endowment]] is [[List of colleges and universities in the United States by endowment|among the largest]] of any university. {{as of|2019|October}}, 53 [[MacArthur Fellows Program|MacArthur "genius award"]] winners ([[List of University of Michigan alumni#MacArthur Foundation award winners|29 alumni]] winners and [[List of University of Michigan faculty and staff#MacArthur Foundation award winners|24 faculty]] winners), [[List of Nobel laureates by university affiliation|26 Nobel Prize winners]], [[List of Turing Award laureates by university affiliation|six Turing Award winners]], [[List of Fields Medal winners by university affiliation|one Fields Medalist]] and [[Mitchell Scholarship|one Mitchell Scholar]] have been affiliated with the university. Its alumni include eight [[head of state|heads of state]] or [[head of government|government]], including [[President of the United States]] [[Gerald Ford]]; 38 cabinet-level officials; and 26 living billionaires.{{cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/05/18/the-universities-that-produce-the-most-billionaires.html|title=More billionaires went to Harvard than to Stanford, MIT and Yale combined|author=Kathleen Elkins|date=May 18, 2018|access-date=August 19, 2020|work=[[CNBC]]}} It also has many alumni who are [[Fulbright Scholars]] and [[MacArthur Fellows]].{{Cite web|url=https://topproducing.fulbrightonline.org/|title=Top Producers|website=us.fulbrightonline.org|access-date=November 4, 2020}} ==History== {{Main|History of the University of Michigan}} [[File:JasperCropseyUniversityOfMichigan.jpg|thumb|upright=1.1|''University of Michigan'' (1855) [[Jasper Francis Cropsey]]|alt=Painting of a rolling green landscape with trees with a row of white buildings in the background]] The University of Michigan was established in Detroit on August 26, 1817, as the [[History of the University of Michigan#The Catholepistemiad (1817–1821)|''Catholepistemiad'']], or the University of Michigania, by the governor and judges of [[Michigan Territory]]. Judge [[Augustus B. Woodward]] specifically invited The [[John Monteith (minister)|Rev. John Monteith]] and Father [[Gabriel Richard]], a Catholic priest, to establish the institution. Monteith became its first president and held seven of the professorships, and Richard was vice president and held the other six professorships. Concurrently, Ann Arbor had set aside {{convert|40|acre|ha}} in the hopes of being selected as the state capital. But when [[Lansing, Michigan|Lansing]] was chosen as the state capital, the city offered the land for a university. What would become the university moved to [[Ann Arbor, Michigan|Ann Arbor]] in 1837 thanks to Governor [[Stevens T. Mason]]. The original {{convert|40|acre|ha}} was the basis of the present Central Campus.{{cite web|url=http://www.umich.edu/pres/history/markers/diag.html|title=The Central Forty and The Diag (1837)|publisher=University of Michigan History and Traditions Committee|access-date=April 29, 2007|archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6IJirvvVN?url=http://president.umich.edu/history/markers/diag.html|archive-date=July 23, 2013|url-status=live}} This land was once inhabited by the Ojibwe (Chippewa), Odawa (Ottawa), and Bodewadimi (Potawatomi) Native tribes and was obtained through the Treaty of Fort Meigs.{{Cite web|url=http://www.umich.edu/~aium/about.html|title=AIUM: About|website=www.umich.edu|access-date=March 7, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180817172231/http://www.umich.edu/~aium/about.html|archive-date=August 17, 2018|url-status=live}} In 1821, the university was officially renamed the University of Michigan. The first classes in Ann Arbor were held in 1841, with six freshmen and a sophomore, taught by two professors. Eleven students graduated in the first commencement in 1845.{{cite web|url=https://bentley.umich.edu/exhibits/umtimeline/general.php |title=University of Michigan Timelines: General University Timeline |publisher=Bentley Historical Library |date=July 5, 2007 |access-date=December 26, 2008 |archive-date=April 21, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090421020242/http://bentley.umich.edu/exhibits/umtimeline/general.php |url-status=dead }} [[File:1886 University of Michigan baseball team.jpg|thumb|left|1886 University of Michigan baseball team]] By 1866, enrollment had increased to 1,205 students, many of whom were [[American Civil War|Civil War]] veterans. Women were first admitted in 1870,{{cite web|url=https://bentley.umich.edu/research/topics/gendersp.php |title=Suggested Research Topics – Gender and Social Space on the University Campus, 1870–1970 |publisher=Bentley Historical Library |date=September 26, 2008 |access-date=December 25, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090313030542/http://bentley.umich.edu/research/topics/gendersp.php |archive-date=March 13, 2009 |url-status=dead }} although [[Alice Robinson Boise Wood]] had become the first woman to attend classes (without matriculating) in 1866–7.{{cite web |last1=Brennan |first1=T. Corey |title=WOOD, Alice Robinson Boise |url=https://dbcs.rutgers.edu/all-scholars/9307-wood-alice-robinson-boise |website=Database of Classical Scholars |publisher=Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey |access-date=March 13, 2020 |date=n.d. |quote=When the question first came up in 1854 of admitting women to the University of Michigan, James Robinson Boise is the only professor on record to vote in its favor. A dozen years later, when his daughter Alice had graduated Ann Arbor High School, he is said to have been enraged that she could not continue at Michigan, and in September 1866 informally invited his daughter to join his Greek recitations at the university. Some of his colleagues followed suit. |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190123010141/https://dbcs.rutgers.edu/all-scholars/9307-wood-alice-robinson-boise |archive-date=January 23, 2019 |url-status=live }} [[James Burrill Angell]], who served as the university's president from 1871 to 1909, aggressively expanded U-M's curriculum to include professional studies in [[dentistry]], [[architecture]], [[engineering]], [[government]], and [[medicine]]. U-M also became the first American university to use the [[seminar]] method of study.{{cite book |last=Brubacher |first=John Seiler |title=Higher Education in Transition|date=July 1, 1997|publisher=Transaction Publishers|page=187|isbn=1-56000-917-9}} Among the early students in the School of Medicine was [[Jose Celso Barbosa]], who in 1880 graduated as valedictorian and the first [[Puerto Rico|Puerto Rican]] to get a university degree in the United States. He returned to Puerto Rico to practice medicine and also served in high-ranking posts in the government.Guzmán, W. (2020, May 22). ''José Barbosa (1857-1921).'' BlackPast.org. https://www.blackpast.org/african-american-history/jose-barbosa-1857-1921/{{citation needed|date=November 2020}} The University of Michigan was involved with the building of the Philippine education, legal, public health systems during the era of the American colonization of the Philippines through the efforts of Michigan alumni that included [[Dean Conant Worcester]] and [[George A. Malcolm]]. Early on, colonial government officials highlighted the importance of increasing the number of teachers and primary schools in the country. President McKinley appointed teachers from various universities, tasking them with building the foundations of the Philippine education system under American control. The first wave of these men sailed from San Francisco to Manila on the ''Thomas'', also known as the “Thomasites.” Of the nearly 500 who came to the Philippines in this group, the delegation from the University of Michigan was the second largest group of teachers who arrived.{{cite book |last1=Calata |first1=Alexander A. |editor1-last=McFerson |editor1-first=Hazel M. |title=Mixed Blessing: The Impact of the American Colonial Experience on Politics and Society in the Philippines |date=2002 |publisher=Greenwood Press |location=Westport, CT |isbn=9780313307911 |oclc=756515246 |pages=90–91 |chapter=The Role of Education in Americanizing Filipinos}} The Thomasites were instrumental in the proliferation of schools and mass enrollment of students in the Philippines. Ten years following their arrival, 4,000 schools were established, and by 1920, elementary enrollment was approaching one million and high school enrollment was at 17,335. [[File:Engineering Building UOM 1905.jpg|thumb|Engineering Building, 1905]] From 1900 to 1920, the university constructed many new facilities, including buildings for the dental and pharmacy programs, chemistry, natural sciences, [[Hill Auditorium]], large hospital and library complexes, and two residence halls. In 1920, the university reorganized the [[University of Michigan College of Engineering|College of Engineering]] and formed an advisory committee of 100 industrialists to guide academic research initiatives. The university became a favored choice for bright Jewish students from New York in the 1920s and 1930s, when the [[Ivy League]] schools had quotas restricting the number of Jews to be admitted.{{cite magazine |last1=Gladwell |first1=Malcolm |author-link1=Malcolm Gladwell |title=Getting In: The social logic of Ivy League admissions |magazine=[[The New Yorker]] |date=October 3, 2005 |url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2005/10/10/getting-in |access-date=March 13, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200216021140/https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2005/10/10/getting-in |archive-date=February 16, 2020 |url-status=live }} Because of its high standards, U-M gained the nickname "Harvard of the West."{{cite web|url=http://www.peacecorps.gov/index.cfm?shell=about.history.speech|title=Remarks of Senator John F. Kennedy|publisher=Peace Corps|date=October 14, 1960|access-date=August 28, 2010|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101003041524/http://www.peacecorps.gov/index.cfm?shell=about.history.speech|archive-date=October 3, 2010}} During [[World War II]], U-M's research supported military efforts, such as [[United States Navy|U.S. Navy]] projects in [[proximity fuze]]s, [[PT boat]]s, and [[radar jamming]].{{citation needed|date=November 2020}} After the war, enrollment expanded rapidly and by 1950, it reached 21,000, of which more than one third (or 7,700) were veterans supported by the [[G.I. Bill]]. As the [[Cold War]] and the [[Space Race]] took hold, U-M received numerous government grants for strategic research and helped to develop peacetime uses for [[Nuclear power|nuclear energy]]. Much of that work, as well as research into alternative energy sources, is pursued via the Memorial Phoenix Project.{{cite web|access-date=August 28, 2010 |url=http://www.energy.umich.edu/about/#history |title=MMPEI–History |publisher=Michigan Memorial Phoenix Energy Institute |archive-date=December 29, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081229015555/http://www.energy.umich.edu/about |url-status=dead }} In the 1960 Presidential campaign, U.S. Senator [[John F. Kennedy]] jokingly referred to himself as "a graduate of the Michigan of the East, Harvard University" in his speech proposing the formation of the [[Peace Corps]] speaking to a crowd from the front steps of the [[Michigan Union]]. [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] gave his speech outlining his [[Great Society]] program as the lead speaker during the University of Michigan's 1964 spring commencement ceremony. During the 1960s, the university campus was the site of numerous protests against the Vietnam War and university administration. On March 24, 1965, a group of U-M faculty members and 3,000 students held the nation's first-ever faculty-led "[[teach-in]]" to protest against American policy in Southeast Asia.{{cite journal|last=Newman|first=Matthew|title=U-M faculty's historic teach-in of 30 years ago: 'A Vital Service To Their Country' |url=http://www.ns.umich.edu/MT/95/Oct95/mt11o95.html|journal=Michigan Today|date=October 1995|access-date=August 28, 2010|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100602090041/http://www.ns.umich.edu/MT/95/Oct95/mt11o95.html|archive-date=June 2, 2010}}{{cite web|date=December 22, 2008 |url=https://bentley.umich.edu/exhibits/dissent/teachins.php |title=A Decade of Dissent:Teach-Ins |publisher=Bentley Historical Library |access-date=August 28, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100727123100/http://bentley.umich.edu/exhibits/dissent/teachins.php |archive-date=July 27, 2010 |url-status=dead }}{{cite news |last1=Glenn |first1=Alan |title=Teach-in + 50 |url=https://michigantoday.umich.edu/2015/03/16/teach-in-50/ |access-date=March 13, 2020 |work=Michigan Today |publisher=Office of the VP for Communications |date=March 16, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190615174038/https://michigantoday.umich.edu/2015/03/16/teach-in-50/ |archive-date=June 15, 2019 |url-status=live }} In response to a series of [[sit-in]]s in 1966 by ''Voice'', the campus political party of [[Students for a Democratic Society (1960 organization)|Students for a Democratic Society]], U-M's administration banned sit-ins. In response, 1,500 students participated in a one-hour sit-in inside the Administration Building, now known as the LSA Building. In April 1968, following the [[assassination of Martin Luther King Jr.]], a group of several dozen black students occupied the Administration Building to demand that the university make public its three-year-old commitment as a federal contractor to affirmative action and to increase its efforts with respect to recruiting more African American students, faculty and staff. At that time there were no African American coaches, for instance, in the Intercollegiate Athletics Department. The occupation was ended by agreement after seven hours.{{citation needed|date=November 2020}} Former U-M student and noted architect [[Alden B. Dow]] designed the current Fleming Administration Building, which was completed in 1968. The building's plans were drawn in the early 1960s, before student activism prompted a concern for safety. But the Fleming Building's fortress-like narrow windows, all located above the first floor, and lack of exterior detail at ground level, led to a campus rumor that it was designed to be riot-proof. Dow denied those rumors, claiming the small windows were designed to be energy efficient.{{cite news|last=Holmes |first=Jake |url=http://media.www.michigandaily.com/media/storage/paper851/news/2007/04/06/CampusLife/Explained.Colemans.Castle-2827579.shtml |title=Explained: Coleman's castle |work=The Michigan Daily |date=April 6, 2007 |access-date=April 6, 2008 |archive-date=April 26, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080426131943/http://media.www.michigandaily.com/media/storage/paper851/news/2007/04/06/CampusLife/Explained.Colemans.Castle-2827579.shtml |url-status=dead }} During the 1970s, severe budget constraints slowed the university's physical development; but in the 1980s, the university received increased grants for research in the social and physical sciences. During the 1980s and 1990s, the university devoted substantial resources to renovating its massive hospital complex and improving the academic facilities on the North Campus. In its 2011 annual financial report, the university announced that it had dedicated $497 million per year in each of the prior 10 years to renovate buildings and infrastructure around the campus. The university also emphasized the development of computer and information technology throughout the campus.{{citation needed|date=November 2020}} In the early 2000s, U-M faced declining state funding due to state budget shortfalls. At the same time, the university attempted to maintain its high academic standing while keeping [[tuition]] costs affordable. There were disputes between U-M's administration and labor unions, notably with the Lecturers' Employees Organization (LEO) and the Graduate Employees Organization (GEO), the union representing graduate student employees. These conflicts led to a series of one-day walkouts by the unions and their supporters.{{cite news|last=Saini |first=Kjyot |url=http://media.www.michigandaily.com/media/storage/paper851/news/2005/03/25/News/Gsis-Walk.Out-1429731.shtml |title=GSIs walk out |date=March 25, 2005 |work=The Michigan Daily |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930184907/http://media.www.michigandaily.com/media/storage/paper851/news/2005/03/25/News/Gsis-Walk.Out-1429731.shtml |archive-date=September 30, 2007 |access-date=April 28, 2007 |url-status=dead }} At the same time, the university was engaged in a $2.5 billion construction campaign after an eight-year capital campaign raised $3.11 billion, at the time a record for a US public university.{{cite news|work=[[The New York Times]]|pages=B6|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/31/realestate/commercial/31michigan.html|title=A Rust Belt Oasis, the University of Michigan Is Spending Billions to Grow|last=Schneider|first=Keith|date=December 30, 2008|access-date=December 31, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090417103447/http://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/31/realestate/commercial/31michigan.html|archive-date=April 17, 2009|url-status=live}} In 2003, two lawsuits involving U-M's [[affirmative action in the United States|affirmative action]] admissions policy reached the [[Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court]] (''[[Grutter v. Bollinger]]'' and ''[[Gratz v. Bollinger]]''). President [[George W. Bush]] publicly opposed the policy before the court issued a ruling.{{cite news|url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2003/01/20030115-7.html|title=President Bush Discusses Michigan Affirmative Action Case|publisher=Office of the Press Secretary, White House|date=January 15, 2003|access-date=December 27, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110305233331/http://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2003/01/20030115-7.html|archive-date=March 5, 2011|url-status=live}} The court found that race may be considered as a factor in university admissions in all public universities and private universities that accept federal funding, but it ruled that a point system was unconstitutional. In the first case, the court upheld the [[University of Michigan Law School|Law School]] admissions policy, while in the second it ruled against the university's undergraduate admissions policy.{{citation needed|date=November 2020}} The debate continued because in November 2006, Michigan voters passed [[Michigan Civil Rights Initiative|Proposal 2]], banning most affirmative action in university admissions. Under that law, race, gender, and national origin can no longer be considered in admissions.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/01/10/AR2007011002095.html|title=University of Michigan Drops Affirmative Action for Now|date=January 11, 2007|agency=Associated Press|work=The Washington Post|access-date=January 12, 2007|first=David N.|last=Goodman|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121110151213/http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/01/10/AR2007011002095.html|archive-date=November 10, 2012|url-status=live}} U-M and other organizations were granted a stay from implementation of the law soon after that referendum. This allowed time for proponents of affirmative action to decide legal and constitutional options in response to the initiative results. In April 2014, the Supreme Court ruled in ''[[Schuette v. Coalition to Defend Affirmative Action]]'' that Proposal 2 did not violate the U.S. Constitution. The admissions office states that it will attempt to achieve a diverse student body by looking at other factors, such as whether the student attended a disadvantaged school, and the level of education of the student's parents. The University of Michigan's acceptance rate was 22.7% in 2019.{{cite web|url=https://admissions.umich.edu/apply/freshmen-applicants/student-profile|title=Student Profile|access-date=May 15, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180615195704/https://admissions.umich.edu/apply/freshmen-applicants/student-profile|archive-date=June 15, 2018|url-status=live}} ==Campus== [[File:AngellHall2010.JPG|thumb|left|[[Angell Hall]], one of the notable buildings of the College of Literature, Science, and the Arts|alt=White-colored stone building with columns in the center of the facade]] The Ann Arbor campus is divided into four main areas: the North, Central, Medical, and South campuses. The physical [[infrastructure]] includes more than 500 major buildings,{{cite web|url=http://www.oseh.umich.edu/environment/floodcontrol.shtml|title=Environmental Protection Management Practices: Flood Control|publisher=University of Michigan Occupational Safety and Environmental Health|access-date=March 8, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130514111416/http://www.oseh.umich.edu/environment/floodcontrol.shtml|archive-date=May 14, 2013|url-status=live}} with a combined area of more than {{convert|37.48|e6sqft|acre km2}}.{{cite web |author1=Office of Campus Sustainability |title=University of Michigan-FY2018 Annual Environmental Metrics Report |url=https://ocs.umich.edu/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/FY-2018-env-metrics-final.pdf |access-date=March 13, 2020 |page=3}} The Central and South Campus areas are contiguous, while the North Campus area is separated from them, primarily by the [[Huron River (Michigan)|Huron River]].{{cite web|url=http://campusinfo.umich.edu/maps/ann-arbor|title=Ann Arbor Map|publisher=University of Michigan, MM&D|access-date=March 8, 2013|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130413071623/http://campusinfo.umich.edu/maps/ann-arbor|archive-date=April 13, 2013}} There is also leased space in buildings scattered throughout the city, many occupied by organizations affiliated with the University of Michigan Health System. An East Medical Campus was developed on Plymouth Road, with several university-owned buildings for outpatient care, diagnostics, and outpatient surgery.{{cite web|url=http://www.uofmhealth.org/maps-directions|title=Street Map to Rachel Upjohn Building|publisher=University of Michigan Health System|access-date=October 25, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120818112646/http://www.uofmhealth.org/maps-directions/|archive-date=August 18, 2012|url-status=live}}—The linked map shows the entire East Medical Campus. In addition to the U-M Golf Course on South Campus, the university operates a second golf course on Geddes Road called Radrick Farms Golf Course. The golf course is only open to faculty, staff and alumni.{{cite web|url=http://radrick.umich.edu/|title=Welcome to Radrick Farms Golf Course|publisher=University of Michigan|access-date=April 8, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130330090502/http://radrick.umich.edu/|archive-date=March 30, 2013|url-status=live}} Another off-campus facility is the Inglis House, which the university has owned since the 1950s. The Inglis House is a {{convert|10,000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} mansion used to hold various social events, including meetings of the Board of Regents, and to host visiting dignitaries.{{cite web|last=Duderstadt|first=Anne|access-date=April 28, 2007|url=http://umhistory.dc.umich.edu/history/publications/inglis/|title=The Inglis House Estate at the University of Michigan|publisher=University of Michigan|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071013222511/http://umhistory.dc.umich.edu/history/publications/inglis/|archive-date=October 13, 2007|url-status=live}} The university also operates a large office building called Wolverine Tower in southern Ann Arbor near [[Briarwood Mall]]. Another major facility is the [[Matthaei Botanical Gardens]], which is located on the eastern outskirts of Ann Arbor.{{cite web|url=http://www.aec.bf.umich.edu/campus.plans/Phase1/Phase1%20Overview%20-%204-22-98%20Introduction%20and%20Summary.pdf |title=Campus Planning – Overview Report 1998 (Introduction and Summary) |date=April 22, 1998 |page=3 |publisher=University of Michigan – Architecture, Engineering and Construction |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140423130901/http://www.aec.bf.umich.edu/campus.plans/Phase1/Phase1%20Overview%20-%204-22-98%20Introduction%20and%20Summary.pdf |access-date=March 8, 2013 |archive-date=April 23, 2014 |url-status=dead }} All four campus areas are connected by bus services, the majority of which connect the North and Central campuses. There is a shuttle service connecting the University Hospital, which lies between North and Central campuses, with other medical facilities throughout northeastern Ann Arbor.{{cite web|access-date=August 28, 2010 |url=http://pts.umich.edu/taking_the_bus/routes/ |title=Bus Routes and Schedules |publisher=University of Michigan Parking & Transportation Services |archive-date=July 21, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100721201046/http://pts.umich.edu/taking_the_bus/routes/ |url-status=dead }} ===Central Campus=== [[File:Law library at Umich.jpg|thumb|Law Library Interior|alt=Law Library]] Central Campus was the original location of U-M when it moved to Ann Arbor in 1837. It originally had a school and dormitory building (where Mason Hall now stands) and several houses for professors on {{convert|40|acre|ha}} of land bounded by North University Avenue, South University Avenue, East University Avenue, and State Street. The President's House, located on South University Avenue, is the oldest building on campus as well as the only surviving building from the original {{convert|40|acre|ha|adj=on}} campus. Because Ann Arbor and Central Campus developed simultaneously, there is no distinct boundary between the city and university, and some areas contain a mixture of private and university buildings.{{cite web|url=http://www.oseh.umich.edu/pdf/08_report.pdf|title=2008 Annual Environmental Report|publisher=The Regents of the University of Michigan|year=2008|page=9|access-date=March 8, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130515004102/http://www.oseh.umich.edu/pdf/08_report.pdf|archive-date=May 15, 2013|url-status=live}} Residence halls located on Central Campus are split up into two groups: the Hill Neighborhood and Central Campus.{{cite web|title=Undergraduate Housing Overviews|url=http://www.housing.umich.edu/undergrad|publisher=University of Michigan Division of Student Affairs|access-date=March 8, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130318213559/http://www.housing.umich.edu/undergrad|archive-date=March 18, 2013|url-status=live}} [[File:Ross School Exterior.jpg|thumb|left|The Ross School of Business at the University of Michigan.]] Central Campus is the location of the [[University of Michigan College of Literature, Science, and the Arts|College of Literature, Science and the Arts]], and is immediately adjacent to the medical campus. Most of the graduate and professional schools, including the [[Ross School of Business]], the [[Gerald R. Ford School of Public Policy]], the [[University of Michigan Law School|Law School]] and the [[University of Michigan School of Dentistry|School of Dentistry]], are on Central Campus. Two prominent libraries, the [[Hatcher Graduate Library|Harlan Hatcher Graduate Library]] and the [[Shapiro Undergraduate Library]] (which are connected by a [[skyway|skywalk]]), are also on Central Campus.{{cite web|url=http://www.si.umich.edu/aboutsi/campus |title=The University of Michigan Campus |publisher=University of Michigan School of Information |access-date=April 8, 2013 |archive-date=May 15, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130515005725/http://www.si.umich.edu/aboutsi/campus |url-status=dead }} as well as [[Museums at the University of Michigan|museums]] housing collections in [[archaeology]], [[anthropology]], [[paleontology]], [[zoology]], [[dentistry]] and art. Ten of the buildings on Central Campus were designed by Detroit-based architect [[Albert Kahn (architect)|Albert Kahn]] between 1904 and 1936. The most notable of the Kahn-designed buildings are the [[Burton Tower|Burton Memorial Tower]] and nearby [[Hill Auditorium]].{{cite web|url=https://bentley.umich.edu/exhibits/campus_tour/chronology.php|title=A Chronology of University of Michigan Buildings, 1840–1999|date=July 5, 2007|publisher=Bentley Historical Library|access-date=August 28, 2010|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100819203735/http://bentley.umich.edu/exhibits/campus_tour/chronology.php|archive-date=August 19, 2010}} ===North Campus=== North Campus is the most contiguous campus, built independently from the city on a large plot of farmland—approximately {{convert|800|acre|km2}}—that the university bought in 1952.{{cite news|last=Migliore|first=Greg|url=http://blog.mlive.com/ann_arbor_business_review/2008/01/contest_seeks_um_north_campus.html|title=Contest seeks U-M North Campus hub designs|work=Ann Arbor Business Review|date=January 31, 2008|access-date=August 28, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120621034553/http://blog.mlive.com/ann_arbor_business_review/2008/01/contest_seeks_um_north_campus.html|archive-date=June 21, 2012|url-status=live}} It is newer than Central Campus, and thus has more [[modern architecture]], whereas most Central Campus buildings are classical or [[Collegiate Gothic]] in style. The architect [[Eero Saarinen]], based in [[Birmingham, Michigan]], created one of the early master plans for North Campus and designed several of its buildings in the 1950s, including the [[University of Michigan School of Music, Theatre & Dance#Facilities|Earl V. Moore School of Music Building]].{{cite journal |last=Carter |first=Brian |year=2000|title=Eero Saarinen-Operational Thoroughness A Way of Working|journal=Dimensions Volume Fourteen|pages=32–39}} North and Central Campuses each have unique bell towers that reflect the predominant architectural styles of their surroundings. Each of the bell towers houses a grand [[carillon]]. The North Campus tower is called [[Lurie Tower]].{{cite book|last=Duderstadt|first=Anne|url=http://umhistory.dc.umich.edu/history/publications/Downloads/AMD%20Engineering%20Book.pdf|year=2003|title=The University of Michigan College of Engineering|page=83|publisher=Millennium Project, University of Michigan|access-date=March 8, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130515012604/http://umhistory.dc.umich.edu/history/publications/Downloads/AMD%20Engineering%20Book.pdf|archive-date=May 15, 2013|url-status=live}} The University of Michigan's largest residence hall, [[Bursley Hall]], is located on North Campus. [[File:University of Michigan August 2013 037 (North Campus Diag).jpg|thumb|The diag on the north campus]] North Campus houses the [[University of Michigan College of Engineering|College of Engineering]], the [[University of Michigan School of Music|School of Music, Theatre & Dance]], the [[Penny W. Stamps School of Art & Design|Stamps School of Art & Design]], the [[Taubman College of Architecture and Urban Planning]], and an annex of the [[University of Michigan School of Information|School of Information]].{{cite web|url=http://campusinfo.umich.edu/maps/north-campus |title=North Campus Map |publisher=University of Michigan Division of Student Affairs |date=August 16, 2012 |access-date=April 8, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130413075505/http://campusinfo.umich.edu/maps/north-campus |archive-date=April 13, 2013 |url-status=dead }} The campus is served by the [[University of Michigan College of Engineering#Laboratories and facilities|Duderstadt Center]], which houses the Art, Architecture and Engineering Library. The Duderstadt Center also contains multiple [[computer lab]]s, [[non-linear editing system|video editing]] studios, electronic music studios, an audio studio, a video studio, multimedia workspaces, and a [[3D computer graphics|3D]] [[virtual reality]] room.{{cite web|url=http://www.dc.umich.edu/Welcome.htm|title=Welcome to the James and Anne Duderstadt Center|date=February 1, 2006|publisher=The Regents of the University of Michigan|access-date=March 8, 2013|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130330084003/http://www.dc.umich.edu/Welcome.htm|archive-date=March 30, 2013}} Other libraries located on North Campus include the [[Gerald R. Ford Presidential Library]] and the [[Bentley Historical Library]]. ===South Campus=== [[File:DSC 6747 (15185649089).jpg|thumb|left|[[Michigan Stadium]]]] South Campus is the site for the athletic programs, including major sports facilities such as [[Michigan Stadium]], [[Crisler Center]], and [[Yost Ice Arena]]. South Campus is also the site of the Buhr library storage facility, Revelli Hall, home of the [[Michigan Marching Band]], the Institute for Continuing Legal Education,{{cite web|url=http://campusinfo.umich.edu/maps/south-campus |title=South Campus Map |publisher=University of Michigan Division of Student Affairs |access-date=April 8, 2013 |archive-date=April 13, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130413083624/http://campusinfo.umich.edu/maps/south-campus |url-status=dead }} and the Student Theatre Arts Complex, which provides shop and rehearsal space for student theatre groups.{{cite web|url=http://campusinvolvement.umich.edu/article/94|title=Student Theatre Arts Complex|publisher=University of Michigan Division of Student Affairs|date=August 16, 2012|access-date=April 8, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130515005648/http://campusinvolvement.umich.edu/article/94|archive-date=May 15, 2013|url-status=live}} The university's departments of public safety and transportation services offices are located on South Campus. U-M's golf course is located south of Michigan Stadium and Crisler Arena. It was designed in the late 1920s by [[Alister MacKenzie]], the designer of [[Augusta National Golf Club]] in [[Augusta, Georgia]], home of the [[Masters Tournament]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mgoblue.com/facilities/golf-course.html|title=University of Michigan Golf Course|work=MGoBlue|publisher=University of Michigan Athletic Department|access-date=August 28, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100901045032/http://www.mgoblue.com/facilities/golf-course.html|archive-date=September 1, 2010|url-status=live}} The course opened to the public in the spring of 1931. The University of Michigan Golf Course was included in a listing of top holes designed by what ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' calls "golf's greatest course architect". The U-M Golf Course's signature No. 6 hole—a {{convert|310|yd|m|-1|adj=on}} par 4, which plays from an elevated tee to a two-tiered, kidney-shaped green protected by four bunkers—is the second hole on the Alister MacKenzie Dream 18 as selected by a five-person panel that includes three-time Masters champion [[Nick Faldo]] and golf course architect [[Tom Doak]]. The listing of "the best holes ever designed by Augusta National architect Alister MacKenzie" is featured in SI's Golf Plus special edition previewing the Masters on April 4, 2006.{{cite news|publisher=University of Michigan Athletic Department|work=MGoBlue|url=http://www.mgoblue.com/sports/m-golf/spec-rel/040506aaa.html|title=U-M Golf Course Hole Listed Among MacKenzie's Best|date=April 5, 2006|access-date=August 28, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100902035604/http://www.mgoblue.com/sports/m-golf/spec-rel/040506aaa.html|archive-date=September 2, 2010|url-status=live}} == Organization and administration == {{See also|President of the University of Michigan|Board of Regents of the University of Michigan}} {| class="toccolours" style="float:right; margin-left:1em; font-size:90%; line-height:1.4em; width:300px;" ! The Board of Regents, which governs the university and was established by the Organic Act of March 18, 1837, consists of eight members elected at large in biennial state elections{{harvnb|Hebel|2004}} for overlapping eight-year terms.{{cite web|url=http://regents.umich.edu/about/|title=About the Board of Regents|publisher=University of Michigan Board of Regents|access-date=December 25, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081221204929/http://www.regents.umich.edu/about/|archive-date=December 21, 2008|url-status=live}}{{cite web|date=October 3, 2007 |access-date=December 26, 2008 |url=https://bentley.umich.edu/exhibits/regents/history.php |title=Regents of the University of Michigan: Historical Background |publisher=Bentley Historical Library |archive-date=September 8, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080908002643/http://www.bentley.umich.edu/exhibits/regents/history.php |url-status=dead }} Between the establishment of the University of Michigan in 1837 and 1850, the Board of Regents ran the university directly; although they were, by law, supposed to appoint a Chancellor to administer the university, they never did. Instead, a rotating roster of professors carried out the day-to-day administration duties.{{harvnb|Hinsdale|1906|p=37}} The [[President of the University of Michigan]] is the principal executive officer of the university. The office was created by the [[Michigan Constitution]] of 1850, which also specified that the president was to be appointed by the Regents of the University of Michigan and preside at their meetings, but without a vote.State of Michigan, 1850, Article 13, section 8 Today, the president's office is at the Ann Arbor campus, and the president has the privilege of living in the President's House, the university's oldest building, located on Central Campus in Ann Arbor.{{cite web|url=https://bentley.umich.edu/exhibits/campus_tour/preshouse.php |title=President's House |date=October 3, 2007 |publisher=Bentley Historical Library |access-date=December 26, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080820232655/http://bentley.umich.edu/exhibits/campus_tour/preshouse.php |archive-date=August 20, 2008 |url-status=dead }} [[Mark Schlissel]] is the 14th and current president of the university and has served since July 2014. [[First professional degree|Professional degrees]] are conferred by the Schools of Architecture, Public Health, [[University of Michigan School of Dentistry|Dentistry]], Law, [[University of Michigan Medical School|Medicine]], Urban Planning and Pharmacy. The Medical School is partnered with the [[University of Michigan Health System]], which comprises the university's three hospitals, dozens of outpatient clinics, and many centers for medical care, research, and education.{{citation needed|date=November 2020}} ===Endowment=== {{as of|2019}}, U-M's [[financial endowment]] (the "University Endowment Fund") was valued at $12.4 billion.{{cite news |author1=Office of the Vice President for Communications |title=U-M endowment up $500M after another year of strong performance |url=https://news.umich.edu/u-m-endowment-up-500m-after-another-year-of-strong-performance/ |website=University of Michigan News |access-date=June 12, 2020 |date=October 17, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200430155351/https://news.umich.edu/u-m-endowment-up-500m-after-another-year-of-strong-performance/ |archive-date=April 30, 2020 |url-status=live }} The endowment is primarily used according to the donors' wishes, which include the support of teaching and research. In mid-2000, U-M embarked on a fund-raising campaign called "The Michigan Difference", which aimed to raise $2.5 billion, with $800 million designated for the permanent endowment.{{cite web|url=http://www.giving.umich.edu/news/images/pdf/fall2004.pdf |title=Leaders & Best – Philanthropy at Michigan |year=2004 |publisher=The University of Michigan Office of Development |access-date=August 28, 2010 |archive-date=June 7, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100607045731/http://www.giving.umich.edu/news/images/pdf/fall2004.pdf |url-status=dead }} Slated to run through December 2008, the university announced that the campaign had reached its target 19 months early in May 2007.{{cite news|last=Gershman |first=Dave |url=http://www.mlive.com/news/aanews/index.ssf?/base/news-22/117949939798070.xml&coll=2 |title=U-M's Michigan Difference campaign hits goal |date=May 18, 2007 |work=Ann Arbor News |access-date=May 18, 2007 |archive-date=September 27, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927193543/http://www.mlive.com/news/aanews/index.ssf?%2Fbase%2Fnews-22%2F117949939798070.xml&coll=2 |url-status=dead }} Ultimately, the campaign raised $3.2 billion over 8 years. Over the course of the capital campaign, 191 additional professorships were endowed, bringing the university total to 471 {{as of|2009|lc=y}}.{{cite web|url= http://www.finops.umich.edu/reports/2009/campaign/|title=2009 Financial Report – The Michigan Difference {Campaign Summary}|publisher=The Regents of the University of Michigan |year=2009|access-date=August 31, 2010}} Like nearly all colleges and universities, U-M suffered significant realized and unrealized losses in its endowment during the second half of 2008. In February 2009, a university spokesperson estimated losses of between 20 and 30 percent.{{cite news|last=Kroll|first=Andy|url=http://www.michigandaily.com/content/2008-12-08/%E2%80%98u%E2%80%99-estimates-endowment-losses-20-30-percent-end-june|title='U' estimates endowment losses of 20 to 30 percent since end of June|work=The Michigan Daily|date=December 7, 2008|access-date=February 7, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090201055502/http://michigandaily.com/content/2008-12-08/%E2%80%98u%E2%80%99-estimates-endowment-losses-20-30-percent-end-june|archive-date=February 1, 2009|url-status=live}} In November 2013, the university launched the "Victors for Michigan" campaign with a $4 billion goal.{{cite news|last=Gringlas|first=Sam|url=http://www.michigandaily.com/news/university-hopes-raise-4-billion-victors-michigan-campaign?page=0,0|title=University hopes to raise $4 billion in Victors for Michigan campaign|newspaper=Michigan Daily|date=November 7, 2013|access-date=November 26, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202233616/http://www.michigandaily.com/news/university-hopes-raise-4-billion-victors-michigan-campaign?page=0,0|archive-date=December 2, 2013|url-status=live}}{{cite news |last=Vis |first=Bridgit |title=UM launches $4 billion Victors for Michigan fundraising campaign|url=http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20131107/NEWS/131109867/|publisher=Crains Detroit Business|access-date=November 26, 2013}} In 2017, the university announced that the campaign had met the goal 18 months ahead of schedule. In 2018, the university announced that the original $4 billion campaign had exceeded its goal by raising $5 billion from 382,000 donors.{{Cite news|url=https://collegepostnews.com/michigan-university-fundraising/|title=Setting a Record, University of Michigan Raises $5 Billion|date=October 5, 2018|work=The College Post|access-date=October 5, 2018|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181005195053/https://collegepostnews.com/michigan-university-fundraising/|archive-date=October 5, 2018|url-status=live}} ===Student government=== Housed in the Michigan Union, the [[Student governments in the United States#University of Michigan|Central Student Government]] (CSG) is the central student government of the university. With representatives from each of the university's colleges and schools, including graduate students, CSG represents students and manages student funds on the campus. CSG is a 501(c)(3) organization, independent from the University of Michigan.{{cite web|url=https://csg.umich.edu/files/files/FY%202012.pdf|title=IRS Form 990, FY 2012|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141018114552/https://csg.umich.edu/files/files/FY%202012.pdf|archive-date=October 18, 2014}} In recent years CSG has organized Airbus, a transportation service between campus and the [[Detroit Metropolitan Wayne County Airport]], and has led the university's efforts to register its student population to vote, with its Voice Your Vote Commission (VYV) registering 10,000 students in 2004. VYV also works to improve access to non-partisan voting-related information and increase student voter turnout.{{cite web|url=http://www.msa.umich.edu/mgovote2006/about.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071003010504/http://www.msa.umich.edu/mgovote2006/about.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=October 3, 2007 |title=About Voice Your Vote |year=2006 The [[University of Michigan Institute for Social Research|Institute for Social Research]] (ISR), the nation's longest-standing laboratory for interdisciplinary research in the social sciences,{{cite web|last=Frantilla |first=Anne |date=September 1998 |url=https://bentley.umich.edu/research/publications/ISR.pdf |title=Social Science in the Public Interest: A Fiftieth-Year History of the Institute for Social Research |publisher=Bentley Historical Library |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090205080145/http://bentley.umich.edu/research/publications/ISR.pdf |archive-date=February 5, 2009 |access-date=December 25, 2008 |url-status=dead }} is home to the Survey Research Center, Research Center for Group Dynamics, Center for Political Studies, Population Studies Center, and Inter-Consortium for Political and Social Research. Undergraduate students are able to participate in various research projects through the [[Undergraduate Research Opportunity Program]] (UROP) as well as the UROP/Creative-Programs.{{cite web|access-date=August 28, 2010 |title=About UROP |url=http://www.lsa.umich.edu/urop/about |publisher=University of Michigan Undergraduate Research Opportunity Program |archive-date=September 23, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080923081017/http://www.lsa.umich.edu/urop/about/ |url-status=dead }} The [[University of Michigan Library|U-M library system]] comprises nineteen individual libraries with twenty-four separate collections—roughly 13.3 million volumes.{{cite web|url=http://www.lib.umich.edu/statistical-highlights|title=Statistical Highlights 2011–2012|publisher=Regents of the University of Michigan|access-date=March 5, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130113013200/http://www.lib.umich.edu/statistical-highlights|archive-date=January 13, 2013|url-status=live}} U-M was the original home of the [[JSTOR]] database, which contains about 750,000 digitized pages from the entire pre-1990 backfile of ten journals of history and economics, and has initiated a book digitization program in collaboration with [[Google]].{{cite web|url=http://www.lib.umich.edu/michigan-digitization-project|title=Michigan Digitization Project|publisher=University of Michigan Library|access-date=October 2, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100929020751/http://www.lib.umich.edu/michigan-digitization-project|archive-date=September 29, 2010|url-status=live}} The [[University of Michigan Press]] is also a part of the U-M library system. In the late 1960s U-M, together with [[Michigan State University]] and [[Wayne State University]], founded the [[Merit Network]], one of the first university computer networks.{{cite web|url=http://www.merit.edu/about/history/article.php|title=Merit's History|publisher=Merit Network|access-date=September 15, 2008|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207130720/http://merit.edu/about/history/article.php|archive-date=February 7, 2009}}—A university press release called a demonstration of the network (with a connection between U-M and Wayne State University) on December 14, 1971, as "a milestone in higher education" and an "historic event." The Merit Network was then and remains today administratively hosted by U-M. Another major contribution took place in 1987 when a proposal submitted by the Merit Network together with its partners [[IBM]], [[MCI Communications|MCI]], and the [[State of Michigan]] won a national competition to upgrade and expand the [[National Science Foundation Network]] (NSFNET) backbone from 56,000 to 1.5 million, and later to 45 million bits per second.{{cite web|url=http://www.merit.edu/about/history/|title=Merit Network: History|publisher=Merit Network|access-date=March 21, 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070715115444/http://www.merit.edu/about/history/|archive-date=July 15, 2007|url-status=live}} In 2006, U-M joined with [[Michigan State University]] and [[Wayne State University]] to create the [[University Research Corridor]]. This effort was undertaken to highlight the capabilities of the state's three leading research institutions and drive the transformation of Michigan's economy.{{cite news|last=Serwach|first=Joe|url=http://www.ur.umich.edu/0809/Sep22_08/00.php|title=URC fuels new industries|date=September 22, 2008|work=University of Michigan News Service|access-date=December 25, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100610175743/http://www.ur.umich.edu/0809/Sep22_08/00.php|archive-date=June 10, 2010|url-status=live}} The three universities are electronically interconnected via the Michigan LambdaRail (MiLR, pronounced 'MY-lar'), a high-speed data network providing 10 Gbit/s connections between the three university campuses and other national and international network connection points in Chicago.{{cite web|url=http://milr.org/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20020628030018/http://milr.org/|url-status=dead|archive-date=June 28, 2002|title=What is Michigan LambdaRail (MiLR)?|publisher=MiLR, Michigan LambdaRail|access-date=August 31, 2010}} In May 2021, the university announced plans to cut carbon emissions from its campuses. The plan covers all of its operations and goals include removing emissions from direct, on-campus sources by 2040.{{Cite web|title=University of Michigan pledges steep carbon emission cuts at all three campuses|url=https://www.abc12.com/2021/05/20/university-of-michigan-pledges-steep-carbon-emission-cuts-at-all-three-campuses/|url-status=live|access-date=2021-05-21|website=www.abc12.com|language=en}} ==Student body== ===Admissions=== {{Infobox U.S. college admissions |year = 2019 |ref ={{cite web |title=2019–2020 CDS |url=https://obp.umich.edu/wp-content/uploads/pubdata/cds/cds_2019-2020_umaa.pdf |website=University of Michigan |access-date=November 25, 2020}}{{cite web |title=2014–2015 CDS |url=http://obp.umich.edu/wp-content/uploads/pubdata/cds/cds_2014-2015_umaa.pdf |website=University of Michigan |access-date=November 25, 2020}} |admit rate = 22.9% |admit rate change = -9.3 |yield rate = 45.9% |yield rate change = +5.4 |SAT EBRW = 660–740 |SAT EBRW change = |SAT Math = 680–790 |SAT Math change = |ACT = 31–34 |ACT change = |top decile = |top decile change = |top quarter = |top quarter change = |top half = |top half change = |GPA = 3.88 |GPA change = +0.02 }} Admissions are highly competitive, with a 2020 freshman admit rate of 26.1%.{{cite web |title=Student Profile |url=https://admissions.umich.edu/apply/first-year-applicants/student-profile |website=Office of Undergraduate Admissions |publisher=University of Michigan |access-date=November 25, 2020}} In recent years, annual numbers of applications for freshman admission have exceeded 65,000. Around 15,000 students are admitted annually, with a target freshman class of more than 6,000 students. Students come from all 50 [[U.S. state]]s and nearly 100 countries. In academic year 2019–20 full-time undergraduate students made up about 97 percent of the student body, with a first-time student retention rate of almost 97 percent. ===Enrollment=== In Fall 2016, the university had an enrollment of 44,718 students: 28,983 [[Undergraduate education|undergraduate students]], 12,565 [[graduate student]]s and 2,665 [[First professional degree|first professional]] students in a total of 600 academic programs. Of all students, 37,954 (84.9%) are [[U.S. citizen]]s or [[Permanent residence (United States)|permanent residents]] and 6,764 (15.1%) are [[international student]]s. In 2014, undergraduates were enrolled in 12 schools or colleges: About 61 percent in the [[University of Michigan College of Literature, Science, and the Arts|College of Literature, Science, and the Arts]]; 21 percent in the [[University of Michigan College of Engineering|College of Engineering]]; 5.3 percent in the [[Ross School of Business]]; 3.3 percent in the [[University of Michigan School of Kinesiology|School of Kinesiology]]; 2.7 percent in the [[University of Michigan School of Music, Theatre & Dance|School of Music, Theatre & Dance]]; and 2 percent in the School of Nursing. Small numbers of undergraduates were enrolled in the colleges or schools of Art & Design, Architecture & Urban Planning, Dentistry, Education, Pharmacy, and Public Policy. In 2014, the [[University of Michigan School of Information|School of Information]] opened to undergraduates, with the new Bachelor of Science in Information degree. [[File:West Hall.jpg|thumb|left|upright|West Hall at the Southeast corner of the Diag]] In Fall 2014, 2,709 Michigan students were enrolled in U-M's [[professional school]]s: the [[University of Michigan School of Dentistry|School of Dentistry]] (628 students), [[University of Michigan Law School|Law School]] (1,047 students), [[University of Michigan Medical School|Medical School]] (1,300 students), and [[University of Michigan College of Pharmacy|College of Pharmacy]] (436 students). ==Student life== ===Residential life=== {{Main|University of Michigan Housing}} [[File:A picture of the University of Michigan campus in Ann Arbor, Michigan, USA.jpg|thumb|Lawyers Club and Munger Residences|alt=Lawyers Club and Munger Residences]] The University of Michigan's campus housing system can accommodate approximately 10,000 students, or nearly 25 percent of the total student population at the university.{{cite web|url=http://www.housing.umich.edu/about|title=About University Housing|publisher=University of Michigan Housing|access-date=August 29, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100817192131/http://www.housing.umich.edu/about|archive-date=August 17, 2010|url-status=live}} The residence halls are located in three distinct geographic areas on campus: Central Campus, Hill Area (between Central Campus and the University of Michigan Medical Center) and North Campus. Family housing is located on North Campus and mainly serves graduate students. The largest residence hall has a capacity of 1,270 students,{{cite web|url=http://www.housing.umich.edu/reshalls/overviews#/bursley-hall|title=Residence Hall Overviews Bursley Hall|publisher=University of Michigan Housing|access-date=August 29, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100820202444/http://www.housing.umich.edu/reshalls/overviews/#/bursley-hall|archive-date=August 20, 2010|url-status=live}} while the smallest accommodates 25 residents.{{cite web|url=http://www.housing.umich.edu/reshalls/overviews#/henderson-house|title=Residence Hall Overviews Henderson House|publisher=University of Michigan Housing|access-date=August 29, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100820202444/http://www.housing.umich.edu/reshalls/overviews/#/henderson-house|archive-date=August 20, 2010|url-status=live}} A majority of upper-division and graduate students live in off-campus apartments, houses, and [[Housing cooperative|cooperatives]], with the largest concentrations in the Central and South Campus areas. The residential system has a number of "living-learning communities" where academic activities and residential life are combined. These communities focus on areas such as research through the Michigan Research and Discovery Scholars, medical sciences, [[community service]] and the [[German language]].{{cite web|url=http://www.housing.umich.edu/reshalls/learning-communities|title=Michigan Learning Communities|publisher=UM Undergraduate Housing|access-date=August 29, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100823144116/http://www.housing.umich.edu/reshalls/learning-communities|archive-date=August 23, 2010|url-status=live}} The Michigan Research and Discovery Scholars and the Women in Science and Engineering Residence Program are housed in Mosher-Jordan Hall. Retrieved February 8, 2012. ===Groups and activities=== [[File:Michigan Union 2009.JPG|thumb|[[Michigan Union]]|alt=Red brick building with large windows, tall central tower, and green ivy growing on the facade]] The university lists 1,438 student organizations.{{cite web|url=http://uuis.umich.edu/maizepgs/|title=University of Michigan Directory of Student Organizations – Maize Pages|publisher=University of Michigan Student Assembly|access-date=May 22, 2012|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101124035157/http://uuis.umich.edu/maizepgs/|archive-date=November 24, 2010}} With a history of student activism, some of the most visible groups include those dedicated to causes such as [[civil rights]] and [[labor rights]], such as local chapters of [[Students for a Democratic Society (2006 organization)|Students for a Democratic Society]] and United Students Against Sweatshops (USAS). The latter group seeks to hold accountable multinational companies that exploit their workers in factories around the world where college apparel is produced. Although the student body generally leans toward [[left-wing politics]],{{cite news|last=Bakopoulos |first=Dean |url=http://www.pub.umich.edu/daily/1997/apr/04-17-97/week/arts21.html |work=The Michigan Daily |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090525140204/http://www.pub.umich.edu/daily/1997/apr/04-17-97/week/arts21.html |archive-date=May 25, 2009 |title=Places I'll remember: A farewell to Ann Arbor |date=April 17, 1997 |access-date=August 29, 2010 |url-status=dead }} there are also conservative groups, such as [[Young Americans for Freedom]], and non-partisan groups, such as the Roosevelt Institute. The university's [[Spectrum Center (community center)|Spectrum Center]] is the oldest collegiate [[LGBT student center]] in the U.S.https://aadl.org/research/sites/um?p__=&page=9 There are also several engineering projects teams, including the [[University of Michigan Solar Car Team]], which has placed first in the [[North American Solar Challenge]] six times and third in the [[World Solar Challenge]] four times.{{cite web|url=http://solarcar.engin.umich.edu/about/pastteams |title=About Us – Past Teams |publisher=UM Solar Car Teams |access-date=August 31, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100705142947/http://www.solarcar.engin.umich.edu/about/pastteams |archive-date=July 5, 2010 |url-status=dead }} Michigan Interactive Investments, the [[TAMID Israel Investment Group]], and the Michigan Economics Society{{cite web|title=About Us |publisher=Michigan Economic Society |access-date=March 5, 2013 |url=http://www.mesclub.org/pages/aboutUs |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101129133838/http://www.mesclub.org/pages/aboutUs |archive-date=November 29, 2010 |url-status=dead }} are also affiliated with the university. The university also showcases many community service organizations and charitable projects, including [[Foundation for International Medical Relief of Children]], Dance Marathon at the University of Michigan,{{cite web|url=http://www.dmum.org/|title=Meet DMUM|publisher=Dance Marathon, Inc.|access-date=August 31, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100908154826/http://www.dmum.org/|archive-date=September 8, 2010|url-status=live}} [[The Detroit Partnership]], [[Relay for Life|Relay For Life]], U-M Stars for the Make-A-Wish Foundation, InnoWorks at the University of Michigan, SERVE, Letters to Success, PROVIDES, [[Circle K International|Circle K]], [[Habitat for Humanity]],{{cite web|url=http://www.habitatum.org/|title=UM Habitat for Humanity|publisher=UM Habitat for Humanity|access-date=July 14, 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140829101244/http://www.habitatum.org/|archive-date=August 29, 2014|url-status=live}} and Ann Arbor Reaching Out. [[Intramural sports]] are popular, and there are recreation facilities for each of the three campuses.{{cite web|publisher=UM Department of Recreational Sports |url=http://www.recsports.umich.edu/facilities/descriptions.html |title=About Our Facilities |date=January 22, 2007 |access-date=April 28, 2007 |archive-date=February 9, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080209120744/http://www.recsports.umich.edu/facilities/descriptions.html |url-status=dead }} [[File:Phi Delta Phi Fraternity House, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Michigan.JPG|thumb|left|[[Phi Delta Phi]], the oldest legal organization in continuous existence in the United States.]] [[Fraternities and sororities]] play a role in the university's social life; approximately 17% of undergraduates are involved in Greek life. Membership numbers for the 2009–2010 school year reached the highest in the last two decades. Four different Greek councils—the Interfraternity Council, Multicultural Greek Council, [[National Pan-Hellenic Council]], and Panhellenic Association—represent most Greek organizations. Each council has a different recruitment process.{{cite web|url=https://greeklife.umich.edu/|title=Welcome to Greek Life|publisher=Division of Student Affairs – Greek Life at the University of Michigan|access-date=August 29, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110328190256/http://greeklife.umich.edu/|archive-date=March 28, 2011|url-status=live}} [[File:Chi Omega Fraternity House, 1525 Washtenaw Avenue, Ann Arbor, Michigan - panoramio.jpg|thumb|[[Chi Omega]] Fraternity House]] The [[Michigan Union]] and Michigan League are student activity centers located on Central Campus; Pierpont Commons is on North Campus. The Michigan Union houses a majority of student groups, including the student government. The William Monroe Trotter House, located east of Central Campus, is a multicultural student center operated by the university's Office of Multi-Ethnic Student Affairs.{{cite web|url=http://mesa.umich.edu/trotter/|title=About the Trotter Multicultural Center|publisher=University of Michigan Division of Student Affairs|access-date=August 31, 2010|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100823141107/http://www.mesa.umich.edu/trotter/|archive-date=August 23, 2010}} The University Activities Center (UAC) is a student-run programming organization and is composed of 14 committees.{{cite web|url=http://www.umuac.org/|title=About UAC|publisher=University Activities Center|access-date=February 16, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100110214530/http://www.umuac.org/|archive-date=January 10, 2010|url-status=live}} Each group involves students in the planning and execution of a variety of events both on and off campus. The [[Michigan Marching Band]], composed of more than 350 students from almost all of U-M's schools,{{cite web|url=http://mmb.music.umich.edu/sections/|title=Sections|publisher=The Michigan Marching Band|access-date=August 29, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100923133257/http://mmb.music.umich.edu/sections/|archive-date=September 23, 2010|url-status=dead}} is the university's [[marching band]]. Over 100 years old,{{cite web|title=History|publisher=The Michigan Marching Band|url=http://mmb.music.umich.edu/history/|access-date=August 29, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100612012451/https://mmb.music.umich.edu/history/|archive-date=June 12, 2010|url-status=dead}} the band performs at every home football game and travels to at least one away game a year. The student-run and led [[University of Michigan Pops Orchestra]] is another musical ensemble that attracts students from all academic backgrounds. It performs regularly in the [[Michigan Theater (Ann Arbor)|Michigan Theater]]. The [[University of Michigan Men's Glee Club]], founded in 1859 and the [[Glee club#Oldest United States collegiate glee clubs|second oldest]] such group in the country, is a men's chorus with over 100 members.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/08/arts/music/yale-glee-club-at-150-at-carnegie-hall.html|work=The New York Times|first=Kathryn|last=Shattuck|title=Yale Glee Club at 150, at Carnegie Hall|date=April 7, 2011|access-date=February 25, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160723014415/http://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/08/arts/music/yale-glee-club-at-150-at-carnegie-hall.html|archive-date=July 23, 2016|url-status=live}} Its eight-member subset [[a cappella]] group, the [[University of Michigan Friars]], which was founded in 1955, is the oldest currently running ''a cappella'' group on campus.{{cite web|url=http://www.ummgc.org/friars/history.html|title=Our History|publisher=The University of Michigan Friars|access-date=August 29, 2010|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100831110950/http://www.ummgc.org/friars/history.html|archive-date=August 31, 2010}} The University of Michigan is also home to over twenty other a cappella groups, including Amazin' Blue, The Michigan G-Men, and [[Compulsive Lyres]], all of which have competed at the International Championship of Collegiate A Cappella (ICCA) finals in New York City. Compulsive Lyres are the first and only group from Michigan to claim an ICCA title, having won in 2002.{{Cite web|title=A cappella group wins international championship|url=https://www.michigandaily.com/content/cappella-group-wins-international-championship|access-date=October 6, 2020|website=The Michigan Daily|language=en}} The Michigan G-Men are one of only six groups in the country to compete at ICCA finals four times, one of only two TTBB ensembles to do so, and placed third at the competition in 2015.{{Cite web|date=August 12, 2015|title=Results|url=https://varsityvocals.com/results-page/|access-date=October 6, 2020|website=Varsity Vocals|language=en-US}} Amazin' Blue placed fourth at ICCA finals in 2017. In 2020, The A Cappella Archive ranked The Michigan G-Men and Amazin' Blue at #7 and #13, respectively, out of all groups that have ever competed in ICCA.{{Cite web|title=The A Cappella Archive – Rankings & Records|url=https://sites.google.com/view/the-a-cappella-archive/varsity-vocals/rankings-records|access-date=October 6, 2020|website=sites.google.com|language=en-US}} The University of Michigan also encourages many cultural and ethnic student organizations on campus. There are currently over 317 organizations under this category.{{cite web|url=https://maizepages.umich.edu/organizations|title=University of Michigan Maize Pages – Organizations|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141209040401/https://maizepages.umich.edu/organizations|archive-date=December 9, 2014}} There are organizations for almost every culture from the Arab Student Association to Persian Student Association{{cite web|url=https://maizepages.umich.edu/organization/ArabStudentAssociation|title=Arab Student Association – Home|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141209040456/https://maizepages.umich.edu/organization/ArabStudentAssociation|archive-date=December 9, 2014}} to African Students Association{{cite web|url=https://maizepages.umich.edu/organization/michiganafricans|title=African Students Association – Home|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141209040719/https://maizepages.umich.edu/organization/michiganafricans|archive-date=December 9, 2014}} to even the Egyptian Student Association.{{cite web|url=https://maizepages.umich.edu/organization/egyptians|title=Egyptian Student Association – Home|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141209040716/https://maizepages.umich.edu/organization/egyptians|archive-date=December 9, 2014}} These organizations hope to promote various aspects of their culture along with raising political and social awareness around campus by hosting an assortment of events throughout the school year. These clubs also help students make this large University into a smaller community to help find people with similar interests and backgrounds. === Collegiate secret societies === The University of Michigan hosts three secret societies: Michigauma, Adara, and the Vulcans. Michigauma and Adara were once under the umbrella group "The Tower Society", the name referring to their historical locations in the Michigan Union tower. Michigauma was all-male while Adara was all-female, although both later became co-ed. *[[Order of Angell|Michigauma]], more recently known as the Order of Angell, was formed in 1902 by a group of seniors in coordination with University president James Burrill Angell. The group disbanded itself in 2021 due to public concerns about elitism and the society's history. The group was granted a lease for the top floor of the Michigan Union tower in 1932, which they referred to as the "tomb," but the society vacated the space in 2000. Until more recent reforms, the group's rituals were inspired by the culture of [[Native Americans of the United States|Native Americans]].{{cite web |url=http://www.goodspeedupdate.com/michigamua-images.html |title=Michigamua Image Gallery |access-date=2008-05-09}} Some factions on campus identified Michigauma as a [[secret society]], but many disputed that characterization, as its member list has been published some years in ''[[The Michigan Daily]]'' and the ''[[Michiganensian]]'', and online since 2006 reforms. *Adara, known as Phoenix, was formed in the late 1970s by women leaders on campus and disbanded itself in 2021 amid campus criticisms of secret societies.{{Cite web|last=Horne|first=Brooke Van|date=1970-01-01|title=Phoenix, a secret society at U-M, votes to disband permanently|url=https://www.michigandaily.com/campus-life/phoenix-female-only-secret-society-u-m-votes-disband/|access-date=2021-06-21|website=The Michigan Daily|language=en-US}} In the early 1980s they joined the tower society and occupied the sixth floor of the tower just below Michigamua. *Vulcans, occupied the fifth floor of the Union tower though were not formally a part of the tower society. They draw their heritage from the Roman god [[Vulcan (mythology)|Vulcan]]. The group which used to do its tapping publicly is known for its long black robes and for its financial contributions of the [[University of Michigan College of Engineering|College of Engineering]]. ===Media and publications=== [[File:University of Michigan Student Publications Building.jpg|thumb|Stanford Lipsey Student Publications Building]] The [[student newspaper]] is ''[[The Michigan Daily]]'', founded in 1890 and editorially and financially independent of the university. ''The Daily'' is published five days a week during academic year, and weekly from May to August. The [[yearbook]] is the ''[[Michiganensian]]'', founded in 1896. Other student publications at the university include the conservative ''[[The Michigan Review]]'' and the progressive ''Michigan Independent''. The humor publication ''[[Gargoyle Humor Magazine]]'' is also published by Michigan students. [[WCBN-FM]] (88.3 FM) is the student-run [[college radio]] station which plays in [[Freeform (radio format)|freeform format]]. WOLV-TV is the student-run television station that is primarily shown on the university's cable television system. WJJX was previously the school's student-run radio station. A [[carrier current]] station, it was launched in 1953.{{cite book |last1 = Smith |first1 = Patti F. |last2 = Woodman |first2 = Britain |year = 2019 |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=7cSYDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA89 |title = Vanishing Ann Arbor |location = Chicago [[Arcadia Publishing]] |page = 89 |isbn = 9781439666975 |access-date = March 9, 2020 |via = Google Books }} Several [[academic journal]]s are published at the university: * The Law School publishes the well-regarded ''[[Michigan Law Review]]'' and six other [[law journal]]s: The ''[[Michigan Journal of Environmental and Administrative Law]]'', ''[[University of Michigan Journal of Law Reform]]'', ''[[Michigan Journal of Race & Law]]'', ''[[Michigan Telecommunications and Technology Law Review]]'', ''Michigan Journal of International Law'', and ''[[Michigan Journal of Gender and Law]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.law.umich.edu/journalsandorgs/Pages/orgs.aspx|title=Journals and Student Organizations|publisher=The University of Michigan Law School|access-date=April 8, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130513090957/http://www.law.umich.edu/journalsandorgs/Pages/orgs.aspx|archive-date=May 13, 2013|url-status=live}} * The Ross School of Business publishes the ''[[Michigan Journal of Business]]''. * Several undergraduate journals are also published at the university, including the ''[[Michigan Journal of Political Science]]'', ''Michigan Journal of History'', ''University of Michigan Undergraduate Research Journal'', the ''Michigan Journal of International Affairs'', and the ''Michigan Journal of Asian Studies''. ==Athletics== {{Main|Michigan Wolverines}} The University of Michigan's sports teams are called the [[Michigan Wolverines|Wolverines]]. They participate in the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA's]] Football Bowl Subdivision (formerly [[Division I-A]]) and in the [[Big Ten Conference]] in all sports except women's water polo, which is a member of the [[Collegiate Water Polo Association]]. U-M boasts 27 varsity sports, including 13 men's teams and 14 women's teams.{{cite web|url=http://www.mgoblue.com/school-bio/mich-varsity-sports.html|title=University of Michigan Athletics Varsity Sports|work=MGoBlue|publisher=University of Michigan Athletic Department|access-date=February 9, 2013|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130301041006/http://www.mgoblue.com/school-bio/mich-varsity-sports.html|archive-date=March 1, 2013}} In 10 of the past 14 years concluding in 2009, U-M has finished in the top five of the [[NACDA Director's Cup]], a ranking compiled by the [[National Association of Collegiate Directors of Athletics]] to tabulate the success of universities in competitive sports. U-M has finished in the top 10 of the Directors' Cup standings in 14 of the award's 16 seasons and has placed in the top six in nine of the last 10 seasons.{{cite web|url=http://www.nacda.com/directorscup/nacda-directorscup-previous-scoring.html|title=Learfield Sports Directors' Cup Previous Scoring|publisher=National Association of Collegiate Directors of Athletics|access-date=August 29, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110102202358/http://www.nacda.com/directorscup/nacda-directorscup-previous-scoring.html|archive-date=January 2, 2011|url-status=dead}} Michigan's athletic teams compete in [[NCAA Division I|Division I]] of the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] and are known as the [[Michigan Wolverines|Wolverines]].
